STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 02, 2023
Annetra Bennett
Samaritas - Southeast
8131 E. Jefferson Ave.
Detroit, MI, 48214-2610
Re: License #: CB820201265
Dear Ms. Bennett
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
12/14/2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not
result in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 734-395-0920.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Pontiac, MI 48342
brownp2@michigan.gov
(248) 860-3012
Enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB820201265
Licensee Group Organization: Samaritas - Southeast
Licensee Designee: Laura Louise Mitchell
Chief Administrator: Annetra Bennett
Name of Agency: Samaritas - Southeast
Agency Address: 8131 E. Jefferson Ave.
Detroit, MI. 48214-2610
Agency Telephone #: 248 -423- 2760
Original Issuance Date: 12/01/1991
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Supervise
Independent Living, Place children in foster
home

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel Records
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the
following information before employment may
occur:
(g) A written statement from the employee
regarding any convictions.
One of fifteen personnel records, one did not have a written assessment
completed by the employee.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home
certified by another agency or tribe, the agency
shall have a record containing all of the following
documents:
(b) Documentation that the foster parent is
2

willing to accept the foster child.
One of three case records reviewed one did not have documentation that the
foster parent willing is to accept the foster child.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows: (b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
In five of 28 USP’s reviewed, five USP's were late. Report dated 7/24/2021 –
10/21/2021 – 6 days late, report dated 6/28/22 – 9/25/22 – 25 days late, report
dated 1/22/2022 – 4/21/2022 – 4 days late, report dated 3/4/2022 – 6/1/2022 -
5 days late, report dated 6/2/2022 – 8/20/2022 – 1 day late.
REPEAT VIOLATION INTERIM 9/27/2021, CAP APPROVED 10/12/2021.
FOM Policy 722-08C FOSTER CARE PARENT AGENCY TREATMENT
PLAN AND SERVICE AGREEMENT.
For both ISP and USP, the PATP must be signed
by the worker, supervisor, parent (s), foster
parent/caregivers, and children 14 years and
older.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, and twenty-eight PATP’s
reviewed, one case record did not have a foster parent signature. The record
was dated 10/27/2021 – 12/28/2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION INTERIM 9/27/2021, CAP APPROVED 10/12/2021.
FOM POLICY 722 – 6B Family Team Meeting
3

FTMs must occur within the required time
frames as outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
Initial case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) –
within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption-At least
three business days prior to a planned
change of placement or no later than three
business days after an unplanned placement
change.
Case closure within 30 calendar days before
The case closure date or one business day
after unplanned court ordered dismissal.
Five of ten open case records reviewed (4 foster care, 1 IL), did not contain
documentation that all required FTMs were held as required and/or the
required signed documents were not present.
REPEAT VIOLATION INTERIM 9/27/2021, CAP APPROVED 10/12/2021.
FOM POLICY 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND
SIGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the
caseworker must obtain signatures from the
following individuals, as applicable:
Caseworker, Supervisor, Second line
supervisor, when siblings in care are
placed apart, Parents who are a member of a
participating household. Youth ages 14 and
older. Foster parents, relative caregivers, and
unrelated court-ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers
must check yes or no for the following when
signing the treatment plan: I have participated
in the development of the Case Service Plan
and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan. I agree
with the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency
Treatment Plan. I have been provided a copy
4

of the Case Service Plan and have the
opportunity to express my disagreement with
the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency
Treatment Plan when the information is
presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or
refuses to sign the treatment plan, the
caseworker must identify and document
actions needed to secure the parent’s and/or
youth’s participation in service planning and
compliance with the treatment plan. The
caseworker must obtain signatures from
all applicable individuals and upload the
signatures pages into the electronic case
record within 30 days of the report date.
Six of 35 PATP’s were found to be noncompliant in nine of ten open
case records. These six plans had missing/signatures from the parent,
youth older than 14 years old, caregiver/foster parent and/or were
missing PATP’s as follows:
• One youth report dated 01/20/22 – 04/19/2022, the PATP was
not signed or dated by the caregiver.
• Same youth report dated 04/20/2022 – 07/18/22, was missing the
PATP report.
• Second youth report dated 01/14/2022 – 04/01/2022, the boxes
were not checked on the PATP indicating they participated in the
development of the treatment plan.
• Third youth report dated 04/22/2022- 07/20/2022, the PATP was
not signed by the youth 14 years old.
• Same youth report dated 07/21/2022 – 10/17/2022, the PATP
was not signed by the youth 14 years old.
• Fourth youth report dated 03/04/2022 – 06/01/2022, the PATP
was not signed by the parent or caregiver.
• Same youth report dated 06/02/2022 – 08/30/2022, the PATP
was missing.
• Fifth youth report dated 10/27/2021 – 12/28/2021, the PATP was
missing the caregiver signature.
• Sixth youth report dated 11/08/2021 – 02/05/2022, the PATP was
not signed by the youth 14 years old.
.
IV. T ECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
5

When PATP signatures are obtained from parents/caregivers/youth older than 14
years old, caseworker are to make sure the PATP’s boxes are checked and the
report is signed to indicate participation in the development of the Case Service
Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation in the following areas:
No Consultation was provided this inspection.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with the CAP is as follows.
Interim Inspection 09/27/2021, CAP approved 10/12/2021
There are three areas in which the agency is not in compliance with this CAP due to
repeat violations documented within this report. The repeat citations and lack of CAP
effectiveness is partially attributed to a nearly 100% turnover rate in staff and
supervisors.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief administrator demonstrated an awareness of the challenges
within the agency as well as struggling with maintaining adherence to the agency’s
previous CAP. This in part is due to the high staffing turnover rate. The chief
administrator identified the need to retain staff, and train staff to acquire an effective
CAP to reduce the noncompliance areas. Staff are being hired and trained on a
consistent basis in regard to internal procedures that are needed to improve
licensing compliance.
Financial Overview
The agency annual budget was observed and reviewed. No concerns were noted.
6

Staff Interviews
Four staff were interviewed that included 2 foster care staff that are relatively new to
the agency, foster care supervisor, and an independent living specialist. Staff did not
report any concerns and indicated that they feel they currently have a stable and
dedicated team. All reported their supervisor and coworkers were their support
system.
Description of Agency Walk Through
No Safety Concerns were noted.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
One Safety Alert was issued.
Concern:
The following safety concerns were identified during a home visit on 8/25/22.
There were no smoke or carbon monoxide detectors in the home.
The basement was not observed due to foster parent stating there was a dog in the
basement and he didn't feel that it would be safe. The foster parent reported
sharing an air mattress in the family's living room until finding housing.
The safety and physical wellbeing of the foster child wasn't verified due to the child
not being home.
Resolution:
Foster Care Worker (FCW) and foster care Supervisor were sent out to the
unlicensed relative home due to a safety alert for the child on September 2, 2022.
FCW and supervisor arrived at the home. FCW observed that there was a family
gathering happening when they arrived. When walking into the home; there were
people sitting in the living area, and in the kitchen area. Foster parent greeted the
workers and sat down to discuss concerns in place. Foster youth was seen during
the visit and was wearing black legging shorts, and a pink t-shirt. Foster youth had
her hair in a bun and appeared to be clean and healthy. Workers obtained a picture
of foster youth for documentation of her wellbeing. Foster youth was very shy to both
workers but did say that she liked Olaf from the movie Frozen. Another safety
concern that was stated in the safety alert was that there were no smoke or carbon
monoxide detectors in the home. This issue was addressed by the workers as they
provided three smoke detectors and one carbon monoxide detector to the family.
Foster Parent went up to the third floor and installed the smoke detector on the third
floor, then installed one on the main floor, and went to the basement and installed
one there as well. The carbon monoxide detector was placed on the main floor of the
home. Pictures of these smoke detectors/carbon monoxide detector were obtained.
The other concern on the safety alert was that the basement was not observed.
During the visit the basement was not observed by FCW and supervisor as the
foster parent told them that his dad is the only one who uses the basement and that
7

the foster child does not go down there. The basement is observed to have a smoke
detector in it now. The last safety concern on the safety alert stated that the foster
parent and the foster youth share an air mattress on the floor in the living area at
night. FCW and Supervisor explained to foster parent that this is not a safe sleeping
arrangement and that foster youth needs her own bed/bedroom. Foster parent told
both workers that he can buy her a bed for upstairs. Workers did tell foster parent
that they can provide a toddler bed for foster youth. The sleeping arrangement
remains the same, and no pictures were obtained by workers of the sleeping
arrangement due to the gathering at the home. After safety concerns were
discussed. Foster parent voiced his concerns that he does not have housing and
needs daycare for the child as he has to work. Workers provided him the information
needed for daycare and told him that the agency can assist him in finding a home-
but that is something he can do for himself as well. The home was observed to be
clean and well-kept during the visit-and all safety concerns were addressed with the
caregiver. On September 16th, 2022, FCW was sent out to the home for another
analysis concerning the Safety Alert. Pictures of the basement, toddler bed and
mattress and sheets that the agency provided, and a picture of the room that the
child will sleep were taken. Upon arriving, FCW told foster parent that the agency
had provided him with a toddler bed, sheets and a mattress for them for foster youth.
Foster parent was very grateful. FCW discussed the plan with foster parent about
the plans for foster youths sleeping arrangements, and the permanency of the
current location that they reside in. Foster parent told FCW that he is planning on
staying at the placement he is at now until he finds a new place to rent. After this
visit, FCW provided foster parent with a list of apartments in Down River, in his
budget that are available to rent. Foster parent then stated that he has a room made
for him and foster youth now that is in the upstairs of the home. With this information,
FCW went up to the room, pictures were taken, and verification of a window was
made in the room as well. FCW explained to foster parent that because he has his
own bed and so does foster youth now, they need to sleep appropriately in their own
beds. Foster parent agreed, no signature was needed due to foster youth having a
bed provided by the agency. The basement was another concern in the home. FCW
and foster parent went downstairs, and pictures were obtained. The basement
appeared to be mostly storage; with one bathroom that appeared unused. Foster
parent explained that no one uses the basement only for storage. Foster youth was
present during this visit as well and was wearing a pink t-shirt and black and pink
shorts. Foster youth’s hair was done in pink barrettes and there were no concerns
regarding the child. Refer to the safety alert to review pictures.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, we
recommend that the agency continue on their regular license.
8
